Task: Informative alternate text is provided for images (i.e. not "spacer" or image file name).
Informative images are described with a clear and meaningful text equivalent (alt attribute or other equivalent means).
Purely decorative images are provided with null alt attribute values (or other equivalent means).
Null alt attribute values are used for images that are already described in text in adjacent page content.
Adjacent linked images and text links pointing the same URL are combined into single links.
Alt text used for images of text include all relevant text found in the image.
Informative images are marked up as foreground images, and not embedded as part of the CSS.
The purpose or function of complex images is accurately described in text.
The purpose or function of complex images is conveyed using a text description, via an alt attribute.
The full explanation of complex images is accurately described in text.
A mechanism that conveys the way through which the full explanation of complex images is defined.
The full explanation of complex images is provided through the longdesc attribute (or other equivalent means).
Images primarily conveying function use alternative text to describe their purpose, rather than what they look like.
Text alternatives of static and linked images do not replicate any information that is already being conveyed by screen reader technology.
Text alternatives of dynamically updated images are simultaneously updated as the images change.
Alternate means of accessing CAPTCHA information are provided, such as audio CAPTCHA, logical question, or other equivalent means.
Images which do not convey information are defined as decorative.
Charts, graphs, infographics and other visual representations of information don't rely on color alone to convey information.
Text content that conveys information is not part of images.
Text that is placed on top of an image is handled semantically through HTML and CSS instead.
Unless a particular presentation of text is essential to the information being conveyed, all images that contain text are only used for purely decorative purposes.
With the exception of logos, all images that contain text are only used for purely decorative purposes.
Informative content is provided through HTML markup.
HTML elements are used according to the HTML specification.
Navigation groupings are marked up using HTML list or nav elements (or other equivalent means).
Header sections are marked up using HTML header elements (or other equivalent means).
The main section of a page is marked up using a HTML main element (or other equivalent means).
The footer of the page is marked up using a HTML footer element (or other equivalent means).
Content that is complementary to the main section is marked up using HTML aside elements (or other equivalent means).
HTML elements are used based on the semantics they provide, not based on what they look like.
Decorative elements are embedded through the CSS presentation layer (or other equivalent means).
All scripting behaviors are handled through JavaScript.
Elements that act as headings are marked up as such.
Headings follow a hierarchical sequence without skipping any levels.
Headings are marked up using h1 to h6 elements or other equivalent means.
Page contains a level 1 heading that describes the page content.
Whitespace or pre-formatted text is not used to render content to appear as multiple columns or tabular information.
Use of native, semantic HTML elements are prioritized over other methods.
The source code (or DOM) order matches the suggested visual order of the design.
iFrames displaying content are provided with a clear, informative title attribute value.
Page title text matches the level 1 heading text.
Pages are described using unique and descriptive page title values.
The tab order logically and predictably follows the expected interaction order of the visual design.
Heading text meaningfully describes the content's topic or purpose.
The main heading of the page describes the content of the page.
Source code is properly nested, according to its specification.
Source code elements are provided with complete start and end tags (or are self-closed) according to specification.
ID attribute values assigned to elements are unique.
Elements do not contain duplicate attributes.
iFrames are given a title that describes their content or purpose.
iFrames are implemented using title attribute values that describe their content or purpose.
Additional content triggered by focus or hover that covers other information can be dismissed by the user.
Additional content triggered by pointer hover does not disappear when trying to move the pointer over it.
Additional content triggered by hover or focus stays visible until purposefully un-triggered, dismissed, or is no longer valid.
All actionable elements can be reached, using only the keyboard.
All active elements can be triggered, using only the keyboard.
Device-specific programmatic event handlers are not used as the only way to trigger interactions.
Behaviors for hover and focus states are planned and included with the design assets.
Keyboard focus states are planned for every active element.
Keyboard focus is not applied to non-active or static elements.
Custom active elements replicate all inherent keyboard behaviors of native active HTML elements.
Non-interactive elements are not assigned JavaScript event handlers.
Users can navigate away from all active elements, using only the keyboard.
All actionable elements can be reached using only the keyboard without requiring specific timings for individual keystrokes.
Single-key keyboard shortcuts can be disabled or remapped, unless they are only active on keyboard focus.
Users can tab through active elements in an order that reflects the intended interaction order of the design.
Tabindex attributes are not assigned positive integer values.
Every element that receives keyboard focus is designed to display a visible focus indicator.
Every element that receives keyboard focus displays a visible focus indicator.
Non-essential multipoint, path- or gesture-based functions have single-pointer alternatives.
Non-essential single pointer functionality is not triggered on down events, unless the functionality can be canceled, undone, or reversed.
Text or images of text that is usually included in a user interface control is part of its accessible name.
All non-essential motion-related functionalities have alternative user interface controls that allow for equivalent actions.
All non-essential motion-related functionality can be turned off to prevent accidental actuation.
Keyboard focus does not move automatically from one form control to the next.
Text labels are marked up using the label element or other equivalent means.
Text labels and form controls are programmatically associated (using the FOR and ID attributes, or equivalent means).
Submit buttons in forms rely on a submit input type, a button element, or other equivalent means.
Related form controls are programmatically associated using fieldset and legend elements or other equivalent means.
Long option lists in select elements are grouped semantically (using the optgroup element, or other equivalent means).
Common group label text is informative, meaningful and provides context for the grouping.
Instructions and messages are programmatically conveyed to assistive technologies.
Use of native HTML controls are prioritized over other methods.
Required fields are programmatically conveyed as such to assistive technologies.
Instructions on how to use forms are programmatically conveyed to assistive technologies.
Information that is relevant to a form does not appear after the submit button.
Data entry fields are designed to autofill previously entered user information when that information is available.
Data entry fields using the autocomplete attribute for previously entered information are set to the appropriate value.
The purpose of user interface components, icons, and regions is implemented using markup languages, in a way that can be programmatically determined.
Keyboard focus is dynamically moved to the error message when errors are returned.
The purpose of the form control is clearly described in text.
The content is designed in a way that does not restrict input modalities available.
Changes of context are not initiated automatically as user interface components receive focus.
Event handlers are not used to automatically trigger a change of context upon input that would otherwise require explicit user action unless previously communicated.
Form interactions are not designed to include automatic changes of context upon input that would otherwise require explicit user action unless previously communicated.
Error messages and alerts are visually displayed across the site in a consistent manner.
Visual indicators are presented to support error messages when errors are returned.
Inline error messages are displayed next to their related form controls.
Error messages are grouped as a list at the top of the form.
Radio buttons and checkbox labels are positioned to the right of their respective form controls (for left-to-right languages).
Related form controls and their respective labels are grouped together visually.
Instructions are in close visual proximity to their related controls.
Form controls are coded to have persistent visual labels.
Form controls are designed to have persistent visual labels.
Clear text-based instructions are provided on how to use the form controls.
Instructions provided in forms are displayed in a clear and unambiguous way.
Placeholder text is not used in lieu of regular text label elements.
Error messages returned provide clear instructions on how to fix them.
Instructions intending to prevent errors are provided in text and available.
Text-based instructions are provided to help users correct errors.
Users are provided with means to prevent and correct form errors when legal, financial, or data information is involved.
When legal, financial, or data information is involved, confirmation screens are provided prior to any final form submission.
Context-sensitive help text is available.
Users are provided with means to prevent and correct form errors.
Icon fonts used to convey information are provided with a text equivalent.
The meaning of icon fonts is determined programmatically using the aria-label attribute (or other equivalent means).
Icon fonts whose default accessible name do not represent what the icon is, are overwritten using an aria-hidden attribute (or other equivalent means).
Background images identified as decorative are implemented as such.
CSS pseudo-selectors such as :before and :after are not used to integrate informative content.
Shape and location are never used as the only way to convey information and relationships between page components.
Users relying on High Contrast themes don't lose information as a result of doing so.
Content is viewable in both portrait and landscape orientation, unless a particular orientation is essential.
Color is never used as the only way to convey information, context, indicate selection or the presence of errors.
For a link that is not underlined and in a paragraph text, its text color is sufficiently contrasted by providing a luminosity ratio of at least 3:1 against its surrounding text.
Regular-sized text is sufficiently contrasted against its background, with a luminosity ratio of at least 4.5:1.
Large-sized text is sufficiently contrasted against its background, with a luminosity ratio of at least 3:1.
Users can resize the text on the page up to 200% without any loss of content or functionality.
CSS techniques are used to ensure that content doesn't overflow, overlap or get truncated as a result of increasing the text size.
CSS background sprites don't include images of text, unless equivalent text alternatives are also provided as part of the HTML.
Regular-sized text is sufficiently contrasted against its background, with a luminosity ratio of at least 7:1.
Large-sized text is sufficiently contrasted against its background, with a luminosity ratio of at least 4.5:1.
The design makes it possible for end users to enlarge the text so that it reflows into a single column without any loss of information or functionality.
Displaying content on narrower screens or magnifying it does not cause multidirectional scrolling.
All non-text user interface components and graphical objects are sufficiently contrasted against their background, with a luminosity ratio of at least 3:1.
Adjusting spacing between letters, words, or paragraphs, or adjusting line height does not cause a loss of content or functionality.
The CSS outline property of objects that receive keyboard focus are not set to zero or none.
Unless the interactive element is part of a sentence or a block of text, its size must be at least 44 x 44 pixels.
Active objects and other calls to action are visually identifiable as such.
Instructions are conveyed through more than shape, size, position, or sound alone.
Additional visual and/or textual cues are provided when color is used to convey information.
Users are notified when time limits are about to expire.
Options to extend, or even turn off time limits are provided.
Users are given means to pause, stop or hide content that automatically updates.
Users are provided with means to turn off all updates, except in case of emergencies.
Users are provided with means to re-authenticate sessions without loss of data.
Users can bypass blocks of content using skip links or similar mechanisms.
Skip links (and similar mechanisms) for main content and navigation are provided at the most effective location in the interface (such as the very first tab stop).
The functionality and expected destination of skip links and similar mechanisms is clearly defined.
Skip links and similar mechanisms point to the expected destination.
All active elements receive focus in a logical and predictable order that is prescribed by the visual presentation.
A logical and predictable focus order is defined for complex interactions.
Objects that are not actionable are not part of the tabbing order.
Focus is sent back to the initiating point when modal dialogs and controls are dismissed.
Event handlers do not unexpectedly send the focus somewhere else on the page.
Link text and alternate text for images, when used as links, describe the destination or purpose of the link.
Links are marked up using the anchor element and have a valid href attribute value (or use other equivalent means).
Multiple mechanisms are provided for wayfinding, such as navigation menus, breadcrumbs, search features, site map, progress bar, steps, etc.
Indications are provided to help users identify their current location within the site.
The purpose of each link can be identified in its immediate context, or from the link text alone.
Content is logically organized using section headings.
Setting the focus to a new element doesn't automatically trigger a context change, such as content updates or the opening of new windows.
Interacting with input controls or other equivalent elements doesn't automatically trigger a change of context, unless the user has been notified ahead of time.
Navigation mechanisms are repeated consistently throughout the site or application in the same relative order.
Navigational graphics and icons used throughout the site or application are designed to always serve the same function and or meaning.
The accessible name of user interface components used across the site or application are defined consistently.
Users can consistently distinguish between links internal to a page and links going to different locations.
Links that open new windows visually indicate they will do so.
Links that open new windows indicate they will do so, either as part of the link text, or using aria-label or equivalent means.
Tables are only to be used to lay out tabular information or data.
Table row and/or column headers provide context for data within the table.
Data table structure is appropriate for the data being included.
Tabular data and corresponding header cells for that data are part of the same table.
Header cells for rows are marked up using THEAD elements.
Header cells for columns are marked up using TH elements.
The relationship between table header rows and table header columns with data cells in simple data tables is provided through the SCOPE attributes.
The relationship between table header rows and table header columns with data cells in complex data tables is provided through the HEADERS and ID attributes.
Caption elements are used to associate caption information with data tables.
Large, complex data tables are broken into smaller, simpler data tables (when possible).
Unrelated data is not included in the same data table.
Tables are not used for layout purposes.
Tables are not used to layout lists.
Caption elements, aria-labelledby attributes or other equivalent means are used to explain the structure of data tables.
A meaningful description of the structure of data tables is provided.
The programmatic order of the table content matches the intended reading order, so not to affect its meaning.
All data table header cells are identified.
Text transcripts are provided for prerecorded audio-only files.
Text transcripts are provided for prerecorded video-only files.
Links to transcript files are provided in close proximity to the audio-only files.
The relationship between multimedia files and their associated transcript is clearly communicated through content sequence or focus order.
Copy on the page identifies when video content has no sound.
When appropriate, further information about the multimedia file is provided in proximity to the multimedia file.
Synchronized captions are provided for all prerecorded video content.
Captions do not skip dialogues or important sounds.
Multimedia player controls are provided to turn captions on or off.
Text transcripts report all significant information from the audio track.
Text transcripts or audio descriptions report all significant information from the visual track.
Synchronized captions are provided for all live video content.
Captions for live audio content are generated using real-time text transcription services.
Prerecorded videos have audio descriptions that captures all significant information from the visual track.
Controls to toggle audio descriptions features are provided as part of the media player controls.
Multimedia player controls are provided to access a version of the video with audio description.
Sign language interpretation is provided for all prerecorded audio content in synchronized media.
Extended audio description is provided for all prerecorded synchronized video content when pauses in foreground audio are insufficient to allow audio descriptions to convey the sense of the video.
Text alternatives are provided for all prerecorded audio and video files.
Brief descriptions summarizing multimedia content are provided in close proximity to the audio and video files.
Live transcripts are provided for all audio content happening in real-time.
Multimedia player controls are provided to turn sound on and off.
Volume controls for page-level multimedia files are independent from general computer audio controls.
Volume controls for page-level multimedia files are visually located at the top of the page.
Audio content that automatically starts on page load lasts no longer than 3 seconds.
Prerecorded or live video content is not set to auto-play.
Prerecorded audio-only background sounds can be controlled by the user.
Prerecorded audio-only speeches contain no background sound, or if they do, must be at least 20 decibels lower than the foreground speech content.
Multimedia player controls can be fully operated using only the keyboard.
Multimedia player controls are provided to pause or play the multimedia file.
Timing is not an essential part of the event or activity presented by the content.
Users are warned that more than 20 hours of inactivity could lead to data loss.
Content on the screen does not flash or blink more than three times in any one-second period, or the flash is below the general flash and red flash thresholds.
Content on the screen does not flash or blink at a rate that is higher than three times in any one-second period.
Animation features that create the illusion of movement are defined so that users can disable them.
Animation features that create the illusion of movement support prefers-reduced-motion (or other equivalent means).
Information conveyed by multimedia player controls are programmatically announced through assistive technologies.
Emoticons, emojis, ASCII art, and other non-markup language constructs are supported with equivalent text alternatives and conveyed to assistive technologies.
Emoticons, emojis, ASCII art, and other non-markup language constructs are not used as the only way to structure content or convey information.
Proper markup is used to render emphasized, bolded text and other stylistic or presentational effects.
Proper markup is used to structure quotes, blockquotes and citations.
Heading markup is only used for text which acts as a section heading.
Heading markup is not used for formatting effects.
The headings used in a page provide a logical outline for the document.
The intended reading order of the content remains logical when CSS and images are turned off.
The source code order reflects the intended reading order of the document.
Site supports internationalization with multiple languages, including right-to-left languages.
Text direction is properly marked up as such, especially for right-to-left languages.
Objects that rely on shape to be properly perceived are supported with additional text information.
Objects that rely on size to be properly perceived are supported with additional text information.
Objects that rely on visual location to be properly perceived are supported with additional text information.
Objects that rely on orientation to be properly perceived are supported with additional text information.
Objects that rely on sound to be properly perceived are supported with additional text information.
Mathematical formulas are marked up using MathML.
Text content in design assets such as content blocks is left-aligned in left-to-right languages.
Fully justified text can easily be changed to ragged right text with a simple action.
The primary language used in the document is properly identified using the lang attribute.
The language definition of the document uses the correct value for language and locale.
Content passages that differ from the default are identified with the correct value for language and locale.
Unusual words, phrases, and abbreviations are organized into a glossary.
Unusual words found in the content are linked to their definitions in a glossary.
Abbreviations are programmatically associated with their definition.
Content is written in plain language using everyday words, to help users with different literacy levels and access needs.
Ideas conveyed through text are supported with illustrations or other visuals.
Content is displayed and structured in a way that makes it easier to read.
Ambiguous words are supported by a mechanism that helps users identify their specific pronunciation.
Information conveyed by multimedia player controls are programmatically announced through assistive technologies.
Status messages are announced by assistive technologies without affecting the focus.
Status, toast, or similar messages are programmatically determined through WAI-ARIA roles or properties, so they can be presented to assistive technology users without receiving focus.
